name: Unicornscan
body:
Developed by Jack Louis and Robert E. Lee.

### Updates:

Sat Jan 5 0:00:00 CET 2013

Happy Birthday Jack! :)

Unicornscan packages now available for [Slackware 14].(https://sourceforge.net/projects/osace/files/unicornscan/Slackware%20Package/)

Sat Feb 27 8:00:02 CET 2010

Unicornscan now available for [Fedora](https://admin.fedoraproject.org/updates/unicornscan). Special thanks to Robert Scheck and JÃ¶rg Simon.

### Overview:

Unicornscan is a new information gathering and correlation engine built for and by members of the security research and testing communities. It was designed to provide an engine that is Scalable, Accurate, Flexible, and Efficient. It is released for the community to use under the terms of the GPL license.

### Benefits:

Unicornscan is an attempt at a User-land Distributed TCP/IP stack. It is intended to provide a researcher a superior interface for introducing a stimulus into and measuring a response from a TCP/IP enabled device or network. Although it currently has hundreds of individual features, a main set of abilities include:

Asynchronous stateless TCP scanning with all variations of TCP Flags.
Asynchronous stateless TCP banner grabbing
Asynchronous protocol specific UDP Scanning (sending enough of a signature to elicit a response).
Active and Passive remote OS, application, and component identification by analyzing responses.
PCAP file logging and filtering
Relational database output
Custom module support
Customized data-set views

### GETTING STARTED.

To begin, please read this [getting started guide](http://www.unicornscan.org/text/Unicornscan-Getting_Started.pdf)  You may also wish to go through the DEFCON [presentation](https://www.defcon.org/images/defcon-13/dc13-presentations/DC_13-Lee.pdf) we gave to launch the tool. You can watch it [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZdCEo6yoEWA).
